Found a Mistake? It makes use of both ownCloud’s technical logs (owncloud.log), audit logs and the
ownCloud Metrics
API to provide insights. It shows information about users as well as storage and sharing usage across the instance and per user. It also makes audit evaluations quicker and more efficient. Automatically gathering and processing ownCloud data enables a continuous reporting tool to be built up for stakeholders. For auditing purposes, the app provides very fine-grained and flexible tools that allow tracing actions by user, by operation or even by a single file and more. The dashboards and tools can easily be extended or modified. The
Metrics App
is installed, configured and enabled on ownCloud Server. The
Auditing App
is installed, configured and enabled on ownCloud Server. See below for further information on these components. Setup & Configuration
ownCloud
Install and set up the
Auditing App
as
documented
. Install and set up the
Metrics App
as
documented
. This value is used to query the Metrics API for data. Microsoft Teams

Troubleshooting
Found a Mistake? ownCloud Server has a minimum version of 10.5. Create an index for your ownCloud data (e.g.,
index=owncloud
). Check all
index = owncloud
settings and change the index name if needed. Check the ownCloud logs locations (default:
/var/www/owncloud/data/
) and change them to the values you configured on the ownCloud Server. Change the
METRICSAPIKEY
setting to the Metrics API key value you configured on the ownCloud Server. Change the
API_HOST
setting to your ownCloud instance domain name or IP address. If you created a custom index for ownCloud data, you have to modify a macro to include this index.

ownCloud App for Splunk
Table of Contents
Introduction
Prerequisites
Setup & Configuration
ownCloud
Splunk
Introduction
The
ownCloud App for Splunk
provides a sophisticated reporting and auditing tool for ownCloud service operators. By aggregating, evaluating and visualizing the data provided by ownCloud, the
ownCloud App for Splunk
allows service providers to gain insights into how their ownCloud platform is used and adopted (e.g., user, storage and sharing growth). The app makes all relevant ownCloud data available in Splunk. Prerequisites
To set up the
ownCloud App for Splunk
, a number of prerequisites have to be fulfilled. Both components of the
ownCloud App for Splunk
, the app and the add-on, are installed and configured. Take note of the log file paths (owncloud.log and admin_audit.log) as those will be required in the Splunk configuration below. Splunk
The
ownCloud App for Splunk
consists of two components that have to be installed and configured in Splunk. The
ownCloud Add-on for Splunk
gathers and stores the ownCloud data in Splunk. The
ownCloud App for Splunk
adds dashboards and other functionalities to the Splunk web interface. ownCloud Add-on for Splunk (TA_owncloud)
The
ownCloud Add-on for Splunk
(
TA_owncloud
) takes care of gathering the data from ownCloud as well as storing and indexing it in Splunk. It requires a Splunk Universal Forwarder to be installed on the ownCloud host. The
ownCloud Add-on for Splunk
does not ship with an index. Install a Splunk Universal Forwarder on your ownCloud host. Install the
ownCloud Add-on for Splunk
If you’re using a standalone Splunk instance, you have to install the
ownCloud Add-on for Splunk
. If you’re using a distributed Splunk installation, it depends on your setup:
Search Heads: Installation of the
ownCloud Add-on for Splunk
is required. Indexers: Installation of the
ownCloud Add-on for Splunk
is conditional. Universal or Heavy Forwarders: Installation of the
ownCloud Add-on for Splunk
required. Copy
$SPLUNK_HOME/etc/apps/TA_owncloud/default/inputs.conf.example
to
$SPLUNK_HOME/etc/apps/TA_owncloud/local
directory and rename the file to
inputs.conf
. Open
$SPLUNK_HOME/etc/apps/TA_owncloud/local/inputs.conf
for editing. Save the
$SPLUNK_HOME/etc/apps/TA_owncloud/local/inputs.conf
file. Copy
$SPLUNK_HOME/etc/apps/TA_owncloud/default/owncloud.conf.example
to
$SPLUNK_HOME/etc/apps/TA_owncloud/local
directory and rename the file to
owncloud.conf
. Open
$SPLUNK_HOME/etc/apps/TA_owncloud/local/owncloud.conf
for editing. Save the
$SPLUNK_HOME/etc/apps/TA_owncloud/local/owncloud.conf
file. ownCloud App for Splunk (owncloud_app)
The
ownCloud App for Splunk
(
owncloud_app
) adds the dashboards, visualizations and other functionalities to the Splunk web interface based on the indexed data. Install the
ownCloud App for Splunk
from Splunkbase. You can do this in the Splunk web interface by navigating to
Settings
Advanced search
Search macros
and changing
owncloud-indexes
to your dedicated index (default:
index=owncloud
).

The app configures Splunk to retrieve and store the data and to provide visualizations, log filtering tools and pre-defined alerts for certain events. With just a few clicks, they can be adapted to specific needs, using the filtering and visualization features provided by Splunk. Splunk has a minimum version of 7.2. Take special care to set the Metrics API key as it will be required in the Splunk configuration below. Both can be installed from the Splunkbase app store. You have to create an index on your Splunk instance or Splunk index cluster. For further help, refer to the respective
Splunk documentation
. For further information, consult the
Splunk documentation
. Restart the Splunk instance.

You will find the necessary initial configuration below. To get started, please follow the steps below. It is not required if you use Heavy Forwarders to collect data. It is required if you use Universal Forwarders to collect data. In addition data and scripted input must be enabled as described below. Enable data and scripted input with a configuration file. On your Universal Forwarder or Heavy Forwarder instance, you must enable input using the configuration files. You only have to install it on Search Heads.
